reference.title: Types of Paper You Should and Should Not Use In A Manual Typewriter
reference.shortdesc: Typing paper is paper specifically used to hold ink from a printer or typewriter. Some typing paper is appropriate for typewriter use, while other typing paper should be avoided.

dlentry.dd: 20 lb bond paper. This paper feeds easily, rarely jams, absorbs ink, and works best with a backing sheet.
24-28 lb bond paper. This paper resists ink bleed-through, and is typically used for letterhead, stationery, and manuscripts.
Papers such as vellum, linen, kraft, and embossed stock are typically used for crafting elaborate stationery. They hold ink well and are thick enough not to require a backing sheet.
25%-100% cotton paper. This paper is highly durable and allows for crisp ink transfer.
A sheet of thick paper placed behind the typing paper, protecting the platen roller.
Printing on carbon paper requires 3 to 4 sheets of paper to be inserted at once, leading to jamming or stressing of the typewriter platen.
Papers with additional coatings to increase smoothness or weight do not absorb ink well, leading to smudging.
Glossed paper will be difficult for the platen and feed rollers to grip, and will not absorb ink well, leading to smudging.
